sicilian.text: A furious storm passes quickly.
A house without a woman impoverishes.
A jealous man is born cuckolded.
A lady has to be of the right cut and the right measure to make a pretty figure.
A lazy woman is never virtuous.
A long dress makes a lady.
A low fog leaves good weather.
A man could die just cultivating fava beans and the kitchen garden.
A man is a man to the extent that he sticks by his word.
A man is never so ridiculous by those qualities that are his own as by those he affects to have.
A man without luck always goes on foot.
A woman who laughs at you has said yes.
A woman without love is like a rose without a scent.
A wounded head can be treated and heals, but a wounded heart never heals.
A year of snow, bodes a good year for olives.
A youngster is never poor.
Accumulation of riches brings wisdom.
Aching bones will never kill you.
Acquire virtue while you're young.
Act aggressive and you will be feared.
After Easter, there are no more prayers and no more lettuce.
A rock offered by a friend is like an apple.
A secretive person is up to some mischief.
A self confident woman will soon be married.
A sheep's wool sky means wind's to follow, either a Levant or a West wind or a Sirocco.
A sick person can eat a fig that's ringed with a crown; the burgisotta fig is a treat for the girl.
A silent woman is a good woman.
A skinny pig is better than a fat chicken.
A small indignity can destroy a great love.
A smart man doesn't give his wife a lot of freedom.
A snowy year, means a good year for grain.
Bed rest cures a hurt leg and a sling heals a hurting arm.
Before an angry face keep your mouth shut.
Before it's ready to eat the fig must be mature, dripping, with a bent neck and a thin skin.
Being in love with a married woman is living on borrowed time.
Being overweight is being halfway sick.
Believe half of what you hear about wealth and holiness.
Believe half what's recounted, the less you believe, the better you'll do.
Believe only a little of what you see and nothing that you hear.
Better a lean accord than a hefty sentence.
Better a poor husband than a lover who's a baron.
Every beauty has some fault and every plain jane some grace.
Every dog barks at a poor man.
Every door has its own hinges.
Every good thing comes from God.
Every impediment is a benefit.
Every little love captured as a playful spark becomes a great flame.
Every new broom makes noise.
Every promise is a debt and is owed, blessed is he who keeps his word.
Every wood has its own smoke.
Every year after fifty brings ten ailments.
Haste makes waste.
Have no dealings with monks and priests.
Having a priest in the house is paradise on earth.
Having health without wealth is being half sick.
Having vision as sharp as a kite and hearing as keen as a rabbit.
He knows little who doesn't help himself.
He that scatters thorns, let him not go barefoot.
He's digging his own grave.
Headaches need soup.
Health flows from the happiness of the heart.
Don't put the bait near the fire.
Don't put the cart before the horse.
Don't put yourself on a par with your betters.
Don't retest the tested because the more you test it, the worse it will appear.
Don't say, don't go, to running dogs.
Don't sleep on the ground during those months that are spelled with an r.
Don't spare expense on the wheat and the flax.
Don't take advice from your enemy.
Don't tell your friend everything that you know; remember that one day you may have him for an enemy.
Don't trust a woman who laughs.
God plays seriously, but He's a merciful father.
God protect us from the Sicilian cop especially if he's from Palermo.
God protect you from the man who looks down at the ground and the woman who looks up to heaven.
God save me from false friends, so that I can protect myself from my enemies.
God save us from a mistaken summons and poorly informed justice.
God save us from evil neighbors and from the indignation of the upright.
God save us from four people: doctors, notaries, pharmacists, and bad bosses.
God save us from the end of March and the beginning of April.
God save you from narrow doorways, a caning, stones thrown at the blind and the weighing of shop keepers.
God would make short work of it.
In July, store the grain under the bed.
In May the horse gets fat, but if he doesn't get fat it's better to ditch him.
In old age your strength decreases and your appetite increases.
In Polizzi you'll find water, fog, kites, priests with children, commissions and delegates.
In the countryside eat cardoon, because at the castle you'll eat pigeon.
In the head of the pig there's something to take and something to leave; in the head of the rabbit there's nothing to leave and nothing to take.
In the olive grove, a wise man at the feet and a wild man at the head.
In time you'll want what you had scorned.
In war, hunting, and love you suffer a thousand pains for one pleasure.
In youth we need to save for what old age will bring.
The less things change, the more they remain the same.
The lie of the millionaire is more believable than truth from a the beggar.
The living who is absent is like a dead man.
The longer you live the more you suffer.
The love of a soldier doesn't last long; when the drum rolls; Good bye, dear lady.
The love of a stranger is like water in a basket.
The man brings the good, but the woman maintains it.
The man makes the house and not the dowry.
The man who chases mules and believes women will never get to Heaven.
The man who loses his wife for good cause cannot be called cuckold.

If the olive trees blossom in April, you'll have enough to collect them with barrels; if they bud in May, you'll have enough to fill a small measure; but if as late as June, you'll only be collecting handfuls.
If the rich man is fawning over the poor man, you can be certain that he needs something.
If the tree doesn't bear fruit, cut it off at the base.
If the winter doesn't winter, and the summer doesn't summer, the farmstead will be in trouble.
If the young had the motivation and the old had the strength, there'd be nothing that couldn't be accomplished.
If they are roses they will blossom, if they are thorns, they will prick.
If you close the door, the devil will turn his back on you.
If you continually harvest without fertilizing the land will soon be exhausted and you'll have bad years.
If you don't collect the sheep early, you get neither the sheep nor the wool.
If you don't have money, you're not worth listening to.
It's tragic to have to uncover a recently covered haystack.
It's useless to change your state, if you don't have luck in your favor.
It's useless to give advice opposing God.
It's useless to tell the lame to run.
January chicks fill the hen house, August chicks fill the baskets.
January commits the sin and May gets blamed.
January hoeing fills the basket.
January's goat meat is so good it even spoils the goatherd.
Judge wine by its taste, and bread by its color.
June rains consume the world.
The world is a wheel, there are some at the top and some who go to the bottom.
The worm grazes where it's born.
The yawn doesn't lie: it wants you to eat or sleep.
The young cock said to the young chicken: the whole world is like our home.
The young man plays the flute, the middle aged man plays the harpsichord, the old man plays the organ.
There are a hundred owners besides you until the wheat is harvested.
There are four things to which you should not lend credence: love of women, the charity of friars, sun in the winter, and clouds in the summer.
There are some with thirty, some with thirty-one, with twenty-eight there is but one.
There are three tasty morsels: figs, peaches, and melons.
There are three who have to give an accounting to God; the judges, the priests, and the godparents.
Trapani, red coral, Monte San Giuliano, beautiful children.
Tribulations and blessings, if you have them, keep them.
True love burns within the heart, better than flax and straw.
True wisdom is born with white hair.
Uncollected olives, left at random fill neither the saddle bag nor the little sack.
Unexpected good fortune, gets more appreciation.
Unfortunate is the property that the owner doesn't oversee.
Unspoken words cannot be noted.
Use fertilizer to change the course of nature.
Use the chicken for broth and the pullet for its meat.
Love is like a cucumber, it starts off sweet and ends up bitter.
Love is the more beautiful when it is a little irritated.
Love is the rock of youth and the shoal of old age.
Love me, love my dog.
Love the one who loves you, answer the one who calls you.
Love without pain is not to be found anywhere.
Love, beauty and money are three things that can't be hidden.
Love, coughing, and smoke can't be kept concealed.
Love, everyone says it's bitter, but everyone wants to see for themselves if it's true.
Lovers' quarrels increase love.
You don't burn incense at an old crucifix.
You don't cast a net into a river that has no fish.
You don't choose whom to love and not love.
You don't light candles to old saints.
You don't measure a man in hands.
You don't spin, you don't weave, or wind, so where did you get this pile of money?
You drive a donkey with a stick, an ox and a mule with a prod, and the horse with a whip and spurs.
You find snails on the mountain slope with the dew from the ravines.
You fool an old woman once; the next time she shuts the door on you.
You get more from a few good animals than from the many that are poorly grazed.
A good kid goat comes from a young goat and a good lamb from a strong sheep.
A good old man is better than a bad young man.
A good rooster crows everywhere.
A good vineyard provides bread, wine, and firewood.
A granita doesn't cost much; still it's just water, wine is better.
A high price moderates desire.
A hitch makes a calf, a sty makes a pig, the open field makes lamb, the hay barn makes a kid goat.
A horse without spurs is like a ship without a rudder.
A hot sun with a lot of wind, I go home and I am happy.
A house that is not seen by the sun, is visited often by the doctor.
By Saint Candelora day if it's not snowing or raining, winter is over.
By the feast of Saint Candelora winter is over.
Bypass monks with a big stride; have nothing to do with priests, except at Mass.
Capacious as the sleeve of a monk and patient as the priest with his arms across his chest.
Castedduvitranu, Castelvetrano, rich in eggplants and good wine.
Cavaliers, priests, and dangerous places, speak nicely about them but keep your distance.
Cheese, pears and bread, is not the food of peasants.
Chestnut horses and surly men can't even cover expenses.
Chiaramonte, a mountain of gold, every woman is a treasure.
Chilblain passes with the flowers of May.
A deadly sin can't be concealed.
A dog for the mother, a horse for the father.
A dry January means a filled hayloft.
A dry year still produces a harvestable crop.
A fat cow makes a thin calf.
A fever in autumn is either long lasting or mortal.
A fortress is made of more than one stone.
A frequent accounting, a long friendship.
A full ear requires three good things: good time, good seeds and good hoeing.
A good fire gives the cook latitude.
What is given by God, can't be lacking.
What the eyes don't see, the heart doesn't believe.
Whatever you have to do, do it quickly.
When a poor man gets lucky, nothing can contain him.
When a rich man caresses a poor man, he's going to take advantage of him.
When a rich man comes to bad times, he doesn't know what to do.
When an old man falls in love he is teased by everyone.
When April is rainy, and May is windy, the year will be fruitful.
When birds aren't making a mess it's a sign that it's been a bad year.
When cranes migrate, bad weather can't be far off.
There's always room for a tasty treat.
There's always time for Mass.
There's honor among thieves.
There's no defense against the wrath of God.
There's no plan that can handle the vagaries of March.
There's nothing fixed under the sky and the moon.
Things for children, apple, almonds and hazel nuts.
Think back, old trunk, to when you were a sprout.
Though trouble be lame, it will arrive.
Three things make a man rich: Earning and not spending, promising and not doing, buying and not selling.
A son who is a priest is the wealth of a house.
A spirited horse, a compliant; an aggressive man, a compliant horse.
A stitch in time saves nine.
A stone that gathers no moss will be washed away by the river.
A strong fire is easily put out.
A tree that doesn't flower in April, won't flower at all.
A trusted friend is a priceless treasure.
A useless watch dog barks but stays far away.
A vain woman is not worth a nickel.
A wealthy man is a pensive man.
Confession without contrition serves no purpose.
Confessions without contrition, and prayers without intentions are time lost.
Congeniality makes beauty and not beauty love.
Cook in June and July, dish it out in August and September.
Cooked pumpkin stays hot for a long time.
Corruptly acquired goods are not praised by the third heirs.
Courage wins over sickness.
Cover a dog bite with fur.
Crooked wood is straightened with fire.
Crowd around for the getting, move out of the way when it's time to pay.
Always ask a higher price, because you can always lower it.
Always use spurs with a horse, whether it's mean or gentle.
Among friends and relatives don't buy or sell anything.
An appetite is a true companion to plain bread.
An empty bag cannot stand upright.
An empty sack cannot stand up alone.
An evening rainbow means good weather in the morning, a rainbow in the morning fills wells and fountains.
An honest wife is a treasure that lasts, a sad wife is worse than the plague.
An old business doesn't need advertising.
An old disease can't be cured.
Age and sins are more than are admitted.
Agree, or suffer the consequences.
Agrigento is a good land with sad people.
Ahi! I'm dying! Give me a hot water bottle and a cloak.
Alacci, remove the bones and be left with the bother.
All a doctor's mistakes lie buried.
All rivers and streams run to the sea.
All the armament of Sicily won't arm fear.
All the fruit will mature in a warm and dry September.
Although there's a new love, the old love can't be forgotten.
An old sin, a new sentence.
An overbearing wife and a shouting husband will never be in peace.
An unfullfilled vow is as if it had not been made.
An unrequested excuse is a self accusation.
April is the time for sweet sleep, don't take things off, don't put things on.
April is the time for the fava, but if not here, then surely by the sea.
April makes the flowers and the beauty, but May gets all the credit.
April, as you see me; May, as I stay; June, as I am; by July, let everything fly.
Around and around, the moth dies in the candle flame.
As long as you don't trust, you won't be cheated.
Bread and cheese, neither beneficial nor bad.
Bread and wine strengthen the back.
Break the soil when it's moist, plow with the warm weather, and do the seeding on time.
Brothers, rivers and priests are three bad neighbors.
Buy at the cost of four and sell at the cost of eight.
Buy good quality and sell at the market price.
Buyer beware.
Buying teaches you to sell and earning teaches you to spend.
By candle light, neither women nor cloth.
By cultivating bottom land, you gain sustenance and goods.
A man without money is like the walking dead.
A neat house and a messy vineyard.
A new doctor is a plague on the country.
A person eating must make crumbs.
A piece of meat with eyes.
A purchased vineyard is tantamount to a stolen vineyard.
A race horse gives you an advantage and wins the prize.
A raised salary has been earned by service.
A red sky means either water or wind; if it doesn't rain, it will be fair weather.
A rich man is a learned man, a very rich man is astute.
Children and the deaf are the punishment of God.
Choose an old doctor and a new pharmacist.
Choose bread with eyes, cheese without eyes and wine that makes your eyes pop.
Choose her for her beauty and even choose her without a dowry because from her beauty you'll get pleasure.
Choose old wine and new oil.
Clear pacts, long friendship.
Collect promptly, pay slowly; who knows, in case of an accident, you'll pay nothing.
Come out of it standing on all four.
Completing a transaction with money borrowed at usury is a bad purchase.
Concern is the beginning of wealth.
Do you want to know the best play? Do good and speak little.
Do you want to make the mute speak? Get rid of his troubles.
Doctors learn on their patients.
Dogs bark and oxen graze.
Dogs that bark, protect you.
Don't be foolish and awe struck, because foolishness is telling but cursing doesn't hit home.
Don't be foolish! because foolishness hits the mark and cursing doesn't.
Don't become a sheep unless you want to be a wolf's meal.
Don't buy houses near convents nor dwellings near abbeys.
Don't celebrate promises, and don't fear threats.
At Taormina every climb has its descent.
At the dining table you should eat without constraint.
At the pharmacy don't taste, at the blacksmith's don't touch.
August rain brings oil, honey and must.
Avoid doctors and always keep them far away.
Avoid the bad, love the good, because things change in a moment.
Bad luck wears out even the stout-hearted.
Be born rich, live parsimoniously and die rich.
Be friendly with everyone and counsel with few.
Be slow to reach for your purse and quick to tip your hat.
As long as you're moving about you can always regain good health.
As Maguni the Carthaginian used to say: work to the vineyard, mind the store.
As the weather goes, so goes the patient.
As you pay the price with the fertilizer, the hoe and pruning determines the harvest of the olives.
As you treat me, so I'll treat you.
Asparagus and mushrooms teach a cook humility.
At Cccamu there are the boors at Termini the brunette slaves; and at Palermo long-stemmed roses, beautiful on the outside and rotten on the inside.
At Caltagirone a hairy conscience and a crown with fifteen places.
At death, one's words and defects are buried.
At fifty a man is either the Pope or a fool.
Who bleeds, earns.
Who builds on sand, the fall is near.
Who can't bite should not bare his teeth
Who can't help, listens in vain.
Who carries on his back is thrown from the saddle.
Who chooses a wife based on the dowry, will have a painful life.
Who doesn't approach with disbelief, won't see the face of paradise.
Who doesn't intend to pay, signs any contract.
Who doesn't listen to reason, can't do things with reason.
Who doesn't make a knot at the end of the thread, loses the stitch more than once.
A bequest, a found treasure, and parsimony make a man wealthy.
A big dog doesn't play around with a lap dog.
A bird shows its worth with its song, an intellect by its speech.
A bountiful pear harvest means shortages of everything else.
A cart horse doesn't last long.
A Christian is more of a scoundrel than a rascal of a non-believer.
A coddled cat doesn't catch mice.
A contented stomach, a forgiving heart; but an empty stomach pardons nothing.
A continuous fever even grounds the lion.
A couple married on Monday is headed for a fall.
Better a woman who is dark-skinned and gracious, than one who is light-skinned and insipid.
Better an egg today than the chicken tomorrow.
Better not fight with the condemned.
Better the bad one from a good breed than the better one from a bad breed.
Better the devil you know than the devil you don't know.
Better to be born a limpet in the sea, than a load bearing donkey.
Better to be shot with a crossbow than rejected by a window slammed shut.
Better to be wrongfully excommunicated than to make a death bed confession.
Better to die and have something to leave than to live wanting.
Better to die in the clutches of the lion than under the tail of a jackass.
Don't maintain a friendship with cops because you'll lose your wine and your cigars.
Don't make friends with monks and soldiers.
Don't make promises to the rich nor withhold from the poor.
Don't pass judgement on a work of art if you don't know how to create it.
Don't pay a single gold coin for the sorrell, but when he's good, be ready to spend a fortune.
Don't plow during September and don't seed during October.
Don't praise the daylight before it is evening.
Don't preach, neither at home nor abroad.
Don't prod the donkey while you're getting on.
Don't push yourself forward if you don't have the heart.
During sickness, you recognize the value of good health.
During the winter eat long fishes, during the summer eat short fishes.
Each wrinkle is an ounce of wisdom.
Earning encourages diligence.
Earnings are of little use if one doesn't know how to save.
Earnings far away get spent along the way.
Earnings from usury don't last long.
Earnings make weariness pass.
Easy come, easy go.
Eat as much beef as you can.
From September to August drink the old wine and leave the must to age.
From the frying pan into the fire.
From the woods a beautiful pheasant, from the sea a beautiful moray eel, from the river a den eel, from the cage a beautiful chicken.
From the work you know the master.
From twenty to thirty, neither pulling nor pushing, from thirty on up a woman is of no further use.
Get a Christian doctor and a pagan lawyer.
Get your ox from a young cow and your horse from an old mare.
Give an apple to the little ones, a book to the old.
Give monks a wide berth, and as for priests just attend Mass.
Giving promptly is like giving twice.
A wealthy man is a wise man: a poor man knows nothing.
A wife and a nag, choose them from your neighborhood.
A woman and the wind change every moment.
A woman in her thirties, throw her in the sea.
A woman is like a cat: the more you pet her the better she feels.
A woman of thirty is not tempted by the devil.
A woman who counsels you either puts you in a skirt or a bridle.
A woman who dresses up and puts on makeup is either in love or a clean whore.
A woman who hugs and squeezes you has deceived you or is seeking to deceive you.
A woman who is young and beautiful is never poor.
Go early to the garden and the mill.
Go to Catania for beautiful silk jackets.
God afflicts, but does not abandon.
God allows but doesn't micromanage.
God arranges luck.
God closes a door and opens a portico.
God gives cookies to those without teeth.
God has dominion over your possessions and your life.
God made things straight, the devil came and twisted them.
God makes the new day with or without the rooster .
When you lose friends, you go down many steps.
When you remove the pack-saddle the sores become visible.
When you see a sheep's wool sky you know, if it doesn't rain today, it will rain in the morning.
When you see many dogs at a bone, it's best to make yourself scarce.
When you see that it's going astray, take the mule by the reins.
When you think you have the wind at your back, that's when you'll be disappointed.
When you try to walk the straight and narrow you get pebbles in your shoes.
When you uproot vines as you plant vines, you'll never harvest the grapes.
When you want to serve your friend, you can't worry about your belongings.
When you work with anxiety during the day, you'll sit up at night with your thoughts.
Don't trust old people and strangers.
Don't trust your enemy's advice.
Don't try to make yourself a land baron at the turn of the river.
Donkeys and women, beat them with a stick, to keep them at task.
Dress up a country bumpkin and he looks like a baron.
Dress up once a year, and dress up in cloth.
Drink coffee while it's hot enough to make you swear but let the chocolate cool.
Dry your feet and warm your head, and don't worry about the rest.
During an epidemic doctors are happy.
During April rainfalls the pig gets butchered, the oxen gets fattened and the sheep laughs.
If you go fishing and catch nothing, go to the henhouse and get eggs.
If you have a business you have to smile at everyone.
If you have to get drunk, you must do it with good wine.
If you have to have animals in your house, don't have either a dog or a cat with a red coat.
If you invest a lot but don't maintain it, you won't even harvest enough to re-seed.
If you leave the safe open even a saint will sin.
If you marry you'll suffer in your youth, if you don't marry you'll suffer in your old age.
If you prune in April you'll fill your barrels not with wine, but with water.
If you prune in March you're either a jackass or crazy.
If you put seeds where there are rushes you won't gather toasties.
Everyone has his own troubles, some fewer, some more.
Everyone knows that you mustn't praise a good wine, a good horse and a good wife.
Everyone runs to cut wood from the fallen tree.
Everyone thinks of his own gain, and plays in this way to deceive his companion.
Everyone wants to go to heaven; the desire is there but the fortitude is not.
Everything goes down the slope and everyone is inclined to the worst.
Experience is the best teacher.
Eyes that you have made cry, cry; so it's no wonder if they tear.
Faith is salvation, not the wood of a ship.
Fake gold and papier mache cost little and look like a lot.
Don't have the appetite of Miss Julia who, when she had meat, wanted chick peas.
Don't join in the celebration or holiday if you feel disgruntled.
Don't kiss blacksmith's daughter.
Don't kneel in front of a saint who doesn't perspire.
Don't leave the small quantity to get the big quantity because you might lose the one as well as the other.
Don't lend out something that you're going to soon need.
Don't let the chicken into the hen house in January.
Don't let yourself get far away from your jackasses, women, and oxen.
Don't look for what you can't find.
Don't love the one who loves you, it's tyranny.
Gold attracts a crowd.
Good land and a good wife bring a man well-being.
Good management and feed give eggs.
Good manners and not beauty leads to love.
Good study and good care banish and break bad luck.
Good wine makes good blood.
Gout is the sickness of the rich.
Grief for a husband is like a pain in the elbow, sharp and short.
Happy are those who are well born, but happier are those who have a good death.
Harvest the grapes as soon as they mature while there is still good dry weather.
Hens feet don't spoil the chick.
Her beauty is the only dowery a beautiful girl needs.
Holy souls! One of them gathers and many eat.
Honesty and kindness enhance every beauty.
Honey is often bitter.
Honor is determined by your dress.
Horses from Ragusa, mules from Spaccaforno, and jackasses from Modica .
Horses should be bays, jackasses should be greys, and mules should be blackish.
How can you get smallpox in old age?
How much is prestige worth, not as much as Palermo, if you take away the saints.
December takes but June repays you.
Delicious things satiate little.
Dig the hoe in well in the vineyard and pull out the bad growth and the weed.
Do a good job of rooting out the turf and you'll prosper enough to enjoy focaccia.
Do as I say and not as I do.
Do good and forget it, do bad and think about it.
Do nothing and nothing will be known.
Do what you have to do and don't watch what others do.
Do what you think is best.
Do you want to experience real thirst? Then try eating bitter cardoons and roasted fava beans.
If you want to die quickly, wash your head and go to sleep.
If you want to eat freshly caught fish, you don't want to have a tight purse.
If you want to experience the pains of hell, spend winter in Messina and summer in Palermo.
If you want to have a happy life, stay far away from your relatives.
If you want to know if someone has money, observe his beard and his boots.
If you want to live to be old you need to start early.
If you want to sell at a high price you'll earn little.
If you want to stay full of good health, always eat eggs and drink wine.
If you wish someone evil, give him a horse, and if you wish him more evil, give him two horses.
If you'd be beloved, make yourself amiable.
If you're not a King don't make new laws; leave the world the way you find it.
If you've seeded before a heavy rain, one out of one hundred of your plants will be out of line, but if you wait and seed later, one out of one hundred will take.
If your neighbor's house is afire, fetch water to save your own.
Ill gotten gains don't last.
In a long race the good horse prevails.
In August the lambs are slaughtered.
In fair weather, in calm waters and in peaceful travel, even a coachman knows how to sail.
In foreign countries money goes by the way.
In hard times priests are in great demand.
In January you slaughter the lambs in February you work the skins.
Better to die than to suffer.
Better to give than to receive.
Better to have a good friend than a bad relative.
Beware of false friends with wagging tongues.
Beware when you deal with sharpies.
Bitter things, hold them dear; sweet things, keep them enclosed.
Blessed is the house that has a son who is a cleric.
Blessed is the one who cares for his soul.
Both cold and hunger make the mouth quiver.
Both water and fire need to be treated with respect.
Cure catarrh with wine.
Cursed is the home where the hen does the crowing.
Curses: like chaff, who throws them, catches them.
Dark ground gives good bread; white ground is quickly tired.
Daughter of a cat, if she doesn't bite she scratches.
Day doesn't come without night following.
Death and bad luck, you take them with you wherever you go.
Death finds everyone and the earth renews itself.
Death respects neither young nor old, neither poor nor rich.
Death will cure all pain.
Don't compromise your beliefs for money.
Don't confide secrets to your wife, don't rent if your house has a pergola, don't have cops as a godfathers.
Don't confront water and fire.
Don't despise a man under a cape nor a woman in tatters.
Don't fetch water in a basket.
Don't fight with someone who has nothing to lose.
Don't give away what you need for yourself.
Don't go to the doctor for every malady, nor to the lawyer for every disagreement, nor to the fountain for every thirst.
Don't harvest grass that you don't recognize.
Don't have anything to do with the cavalier who has fallen into poverty.
Eat little and you'll live, speak little and you'll get it right, spend little and you'll become rich.
Eat meat and fish and live longer.
Eat to live, and not live to eat.
Eat to please thyself, but dress to please others.
Eat warm and drink cold.
Eat with gusto but drink in moderation.
Eat yesterday's bread and last year's wine.
Eating makes crumbs.
Empty stalks from the Sirocco and full spikes of wheat with the North Wind.
Even a hundred people can't undress a nude.
Far from the eye far from the heart.
February may be short but it's the worst month.
Fever sustains the sick.
Finish what your start.
First harvest honey and wax during the day, then dance and play in the open during the evening.
Fleeing is shameful but it preserves life.
Flies can't fly into a closed mouth.
Flies don't get near a boiling pot.
Flowers in May and fruiting in June.
For a cow and a calf you need a man and a stable boy.
The good that you scoff at and ignore, you'll recognize when you lose it.
The grill said to the frying pan: I want big fishes not minnows.
The hat does not make the gentleman nor the cap a lout.
The haughty broad bean flowers and climbs but produces little fruit.
The healthy can't pretend to be sick nor can the sick pretend to be healthy.
The hoer hoes in his own vineyard.
The honorable man lives in difficulty.
The horns are dry but they keep the house in plenty.
The horns of the sister are horns of gold; the horns of the wife are true horns.
The horse chained to the feeding trough and the mare in the thicket.
Justice and fire, keep them at arms length.
Justice and health, woe to the one who seeks them.
Justice that's pending is injustice attending.
Keep up with the times, don't stay in the dark.
Keep watch for the appearing mushroom.
Keep your feet on the ground and you'll lessen the pain.
Kind master, give me hay for all of April.
Kiss him, kiss him, little mouth of honey: you're the hooker but I'm the wife.
Knowledge is no match for luck.
Late marriages, premature orphans.
If you see a Greek and a wolf, avoid the wolf and shoot the Greek.
If you show a rich man kindness, you gain nothing, but when you wrong him he avenges himself instantly.
If you still have money in the month of May, you'll have it the entire year.
If you urge the donkey on, you'll arrive late, if you let the donkey amble, you'll arrive early.
If you want a beautiful woman, hurry to Syracuse: if you want her ugly, run to Terranova, go to Rosolini if you want her lazy and to Spaccaforno if you're looking for one to try.
If you want a celebration provide the means.
If you want a faithful dog start rearing him when he is young.
If you want bread go to Agrigento, if you want pasta go to Licata, ask for money from the people in Aci, oil and sumac from the Terminesi.
If you want to be happy, love the one who loves you, because it's a waste of time to love someone who doesn't love you.
If you want to be loved by all, first love God, then your mother and father.
For a taste treat, try tuna roe and thorny cardoons.
For sulphur, wheat, wine, and wool, come to the towns of Sicily.
For tender almonds go to Aragona, to see beautiful young girls go to Favara.
For the man a great sweat, for the woman a great physical pain.
For the very best, drink milk from the goat, ricotta from the sheep and cheese from the cow.
For women the highest state is the married state.
Force of arms is useless against death.
Forget your troubles at the dining table.
Freedom and health, who has them is rich and doesn't know it.
Freedom is a plateful of hard crusts.
If it isn't wintry in January then expect the worst in February.
If it's a cock it will crow and crow, if it's a chicken it will peck its hip.
If March is late in coming, June will suffer.
If Messina had gardens Palermo would be a bunch of poor country houses.
If she's a nun in the abbey, she treats Jesus as an owner, but if she's a nun in the home, she serves Jesus and kisses him.
If someone can take whatever you have, give them whatever they ask for.
If the dowry doesn't support her, even the executioner is disinterested.
If the mare jumps, the filly will jump higher.
If the mule isn't kicking, it's biting.
If the North Wind takes to blowing, it will rain for a week.
Luck is the friend of jackasses and the crazy; it's a mortal enemy of the virtuous.
Make agreements without guile.
Make your testimony and confessions while you're eating sausages and macaroni.
Mallow will cure you.
Man is a hunter.
Man is like the sea: if he doesn't produce today, he'll produce tomorrow.
Man is valued for his word, the ox for his horns.
Man loses his good judgement over women and wine.
Many are the lords of the cities and the slaves of women.
Marriage and maids, don't suggest them because you'll be cursed.
Latin hides the stupidity of the priest.
Laughter without reason, is either crazy or stupid.
Learned doctors are stars on earth.
Leave in the daylight, don't leave in the dark.
Leave the hot fire and help the woman in labor.
Let a sleeping dog lie.
Let God handle it, He's a venerable saint.
Let me deal with my troubles myself.
Like feathers, words are blown away by the wind.
Listen to the old and you won't be mistaken.
The husband who lacks affection is like a house that lacks a roof.
The husbands belong to the wives and hookers are for the wild beast.
The ideal is a four year old dog, an eight year old horse, an eighteen year old woman and a twenty eight year old man.
The jackass that is late returns loaded.
The January moon brightens like a clear day.
The June bee portends lots of honey.
The justice of God is better than the justice of the world.
The lame jackass enjoys the journey.
The latecomer is valued as nothing.
The laying hen says: give me feed to fill my beak and I'll give you eggs.
Plant vines as long as you live and seed as far as you see.
Plow with the oxen and seed with the cows at their own pace.
Praise the sea but hang on to the land.
Prepare the fallow field well enough and you'll be free to go off and gather the hemp ties.
Prepare the sickles in May, use the sickles in June, and in July carry the sickles to the tool shed.
Preparing for the holiday is neither enlightening nor lasting.
Priests dressed in black bring bad tidings, in white they take you to the cemetery.
Privateer, sail while you have a good wind.
Prune cherry and fig trees mercilessly.
Prune the vines on the January moon if you want to fill the casks.
One Mass now is worth a hundred after you're gone.
One occasion doesn't make the rule.
One sins and is enthroned, another sins and is crucified.
One tap on the keg and one on the spout.
One who believes everything he's told is as naive as one who fetches water with a sieve.
One who is never satisfied is always in need.
One who lives within his means can be said to be rich.
Only God can judge and foretell.
Only he knows how to command, who knows the one who is commanding.
Only Sperlinga said no.
The quince is for fiancees who are fighting and the azarole for good people.
The real cost for both a neat house and a well kept vineyard is incalculable.
The rejected stone will become the cornerstone of the wall.
The rich do as they want, the poor do as they can.
The rich have no pain.
The rich man breaks through the mesh and escapes, the afflicted man remains in the net and is caught.
The rich man has little need.
The richer you are, the more troubles you have.
The rose that's not considered, has been smelled or picked or defoliated.
The satiated don't believe the hungry.
The bands of Palermo and the privileges of Messina.
The bankrupt merchant is half rich.
The barking of dogs does not reach heaven.
The beauty of the play is to do deeds and speak little.
The bed of the Dominicans, the table of the Capuccins, and the luxury of the Benedictines.
The best of all worlds: A sunny Christmas and a log fire on Easter.
The big bells have to ring, in order for the little bells to ring.
The bigger the chance, the less the security.
The boss said to the servant, when there isn't what you want, eat what there is.
The bride's faults are hidden by the dowry.
Sardines in January and vopa in March.
Sausage from Mazzarino, clia from Caltagirone, and pasta from Vizzini.
Scarcity sets the price.
Sea urchins, limpets, and crabs you spend a lot and eat nothing.
See Palermo and enjoy it, see Naples then die.
Seed after a bad year.
Seed ground that has been fallow, not ground that has just yielded fruitfully.
Seed well and harvest better.
Seek goodness and expect evil.
Sell high and give a fair measure.
Stay within your level of competence.
Strike while the iron is hot.
Strive to be that which you want to appear to be.
Strong men, harmful at home.
Summary justice is a summary offense.
Swarms in March make good honey.
Syracuse is a lovely place, with five bucks you can eat, drink, and get by.
Take advice from the prudent and you'll never regret it.
Take care of the manger and water the animals at the drinking trough.
Take her by herself and take her with nothing.
Messina is clever, Palermo is pompous; Messina is rich, Palermo is greedy.
Milk and wine together make an excellent poison.
Monks have both a capacious sleeve and a tight sleeve.
Monreale, a city without comfort, either it rains, or the wind blows, or bells ring for the dead.
More die because they live to eat, than die by the sword.
Morning makes the day.
Most often a good boss makes a good steward.
Mountains will never join other mountains but men will confront other men.
Necessity is the mother of invention.
Neither believed nor understood is the poor who's offended.
Render the service paid for.
Repentance washes away sin.
Rice, it goes down but does nothing for me.
Ricotta and honey, eat them often.
Ride on the back of a mare, but on the shoulders of horses.
Ring the bells for whoever eats snails and drinks water, because he's dead.
Roof tiles are positioned to face downwards so that husbands and wives can be left alone.
Safeguard the flock that is grazing on the mountain.
Saints sleep three hours, merchants sleep five, ordinary people seven and the lazy sleep nine.
Salt comes from the sea and every bad thing comes from the woman.
The more you know the less you believe.
The most important thing you have to do is to save your soul.
The mother bears the daughter and the neighbor marries her off.
The mother of a fool is always pregnant.
The new moon of March rules for six months.
The nightime March snow disappears by day.
The offender writes in dust, the offended writes in marble.
The oil merchant handles gold and diamonds; the grain merchant does business with silver, but the wine merchant is a poor man.
The old have to be respected.
The old never lack for a story when they're standing in the sun or in front of a warm fireplace.
Hunger doesn't have to look for an appetite.
Hunger is the best sauce.
Hunger never saw bad bread.
I'll believe the thunder when I see the lightning.
I'll take care of today, let God take care of tomorrow.
If an offense has hurt you too much, leave it, my friend, for a future time.
If between friends there is not equality, there won't be perfect love.
If Catania had a port, Palermo would be dead.
If February isn't cold and rainy, the March landscape will be green.
If I were a prophet, I wouldn't be wretched.
If you don't hope, you won't be crushed.
If you don't know by age twenty, don't do by age thrity, don't have by age forty, you will never know, never do, and never have.
If you don't like dogs, you don't like people.
If you don't plant, you get nothing.
If you don't want anyone to take your place, don't ever show that you're frightened.
If you don't want it to be known, don't do it.
If you don't want to attract attention, don't start something new.
If you drink a belly full you'll regret it all day.
If you engage in a business you don't understand, your money will fly away.
If you give your goods without a pledge, you show little inventiveness.
The old nightingale sings better.
The old woman doesn't want fun, she wants bread, wine, and fire.
The olive grove of your grandfather, the cherry trees of your father, and your grape vines.
The one who does the dividing has the best portion.
The one who has a fever thinks that honey is bitter.
The one who loses his faith will never be content.
The ox which eats hay, works the entire day.
The pardon arrives after the man was hung.
The peasant is like the monk in many ways.
The pig says: give to me and I'll give to you, don't tell me how long it's taking.
It's always good to have an old man at a little boy's side.
It's better to cajole the beast than to scream at it.
It's better to have few pleasures than many troubles.
It's better to have ringworm than a farm and vineyard.
It's dumb to put snow on the kitchen spit, the snow melts and the fire goes out.
It's fun to be a guest.
It's healthier to wear out many boots and few bed sheets.
It's insane to oppose when you can neither win nor compromise.
It's not polite to eat just the center of the cheese and just the crust of the bread.
It's pointless to fish if there's no bait on the hook.
Only your real friends will tell you when your face is dirty.
Open your eyes and your ears when contracting, because the agreed upon circumstances mean a lot.
Oregano and wild mint, if one does poorly, the other is worse.
Overwhelming courtesy raises concern that you may be being deceitful.
Owning land is like fighting a war.
Palermitani, two tars for the bread drippings and two grains for bread.
Palermo for its illustrious writers and Messina for its harbor.
Palermo is a tolerant man, whoever goes, goes and whoever comes, comes.
Partinico is a good town, good wine and low costs.
Pass by the place that was robbed with confidence.
To get the best dowry, marry the poor man's first daughter but the rich man's last daughter.
To have security, plan ahead.
To lengthen thy life, lessen thy meals.
To recognize a real friend, you have to together have eaten three bushels of salt.
To ward off the boredom of life, eat snails in May and fish in August.
Today to me, tomorrow to you, we're all in it together.
Too compassionate the doctor, too inadequate the treatment.
Too much rain makes the green grain fall over.
Too much spoils and too little is not enough.
Translators, traitors.
Neither the baskets of the farmer nor the baskets of the abbey.
Neither you happy nor I consoled.
Never trust your friend with a secret unless he is mute or a dog.
New advice for a new business.
New love throws out old love.
Night time sleep counsels man.
No matter how often a pitcher goes to the water, it is broken in the end.
No one does something for nothing.
No one ever boasted without paying dearly.
No one is perfect.
The bushes grow in order to cover defects.
The buyer first disparages.
The choice oil is from the surface, the best wine is from the middle, and the best honey is from the bottom.
The Church never gives anything away.
The cockroach inside the oakum, the more it tries to free itself, the more it's caught.
The constancy of women is like rain in July.
The cowherd who has fodder has bread, and if he doesn't have fodder then he ends up without oxen and without bread.
The creditor gets a pledge from the good payer.
The devil knows a lot because he's old.
The devil laughs when the poor donates to the rich.
The man who marries gives up liberty and accepts responsibility and it's said: The poor guy, who would have thought it.
The man with a beautiful wife is always singing, the one with little money is always counting.
The man with a fixed income lives with anxiety and suffers as the costs of goods fluctuate.
The man without a wife, has nothing good.
The man without money seems half sick.
The master is the master and the owner is the headmaster.
The mature fruit is cooked in August and dished out in September.
The meat from the castrated, from wherever you take it you trick yourself.
The monk feasts and the convent pays.
The more you have, the more you want.
Sometimes the rope is too short, sometimes the well is too deep.
Sore is the mouth that loses its first tooth.
Sow fava bean and flax with confidence while you still have a full silo.
Sow with the Sirocco but not with the North wind.
Spare the ox in August so that it's ready to work in October.
Speak little in the company of the old.
Spend Easter and Christmas with whomever you want, but celebrate Mardi Gras with your own.
Spit at heaven and you'll get it back in your face.
Stand by your own whether right or wrong.
Starting is always difficult, but every desire is attainable.
Taking a bite of the bread restores your appetite.
Ten ounces to all, eleven ounces to some, and a full twelve to no one.
That fellow roasts his fish in the flames of a fire.
That grief is light which is capable of counsel.
That which is agreed upon is not deception.
That which is written, is meant to be read.
The ancient motto says: When you can eat the figs, prune the fig trees.
The arm of the young and the head of the old.
The bad collector makes the bad payer.
The bands in Messina play from morning until night.
Little and nothing are relatives.
Long service awaits rewards.
Look at who I am and not who I was.
Love and arrogance don't go together.
Love and jealousy always keep company.
Love doesn't listen to advice.
Love entered and you didn't realize it: you wanted to drive it out but you couldn't.
Love God with all your heart and ignore the gossip-mongers.
Love is apportioned, who brings it will have it brought.
Love is bitter, but it comforts the heart.
The dog bites the bedraggled.
The dog that's late is bringing the catch.
The door is always open to the bearer of gifts.
The drunkard always tells the truth.
The early bird catches the worm.
sicilian.description: You should wake up and start work early if you want to succeed.

sicilian.text: The earth says: Give to me and I'll give to you.
The eggs of the brood need to be an odd number.
The expense is more than the merchandise.
The eye of the Syracusan makes the snakes come out of their pits.
The fellow roasts his fish in the flames of a fire.
When you're enjoying prosperity, be wary of adversity.
When you're invited, eat heartily, because if they like you they'll laugh, and if they don't like you they'll feel the pangs of death.
When you're sick, tell everyone.
When you're travelling, don't speak poorly of your neighbor.
When your neighbor burns down, your hurt is near.
Where malice has taken root, friendship can never be formed.
Where many roosters are crowing, it's not because it's daylight.
Where the gold jingles more, I run more quickly.
Where the hen goes, the chicks follow.
Where there are monks and priests, there is adultery and beatings.
No one will choose you if they're not like you.
No one will steal it from you if they don't know you have it.
Nobel and rich are the Messinans, heads of the kingdom are the Palermitani, the Catanians have a contented heart, and in Cefalu they are rich with fish.
Nobility is less esteemed when it lacks wealth.
Not all the red-faced are drunkards nor all the yellow-faced sick.
Not all the spikes of wheat go on the wheat pile.
Not every pain comes to harm you.
Nothing can end favorably without heavenly guidance.
Nunziata, fix the salad, a little vinegar, lots of oil, four reckless mouthfuls, and then some drinks from the jug.
Nut and fig trees need to be pruned aggressively.
Who has many comforts and does not use them, won't find a confessor who will grant him absolution.
Who has money, spouts wisdom.
Who has never had good sense, and by age thirty still doesn't, certainly will never have it after that.
Who hopes for alms from the priests, winds up at the insane asylum.
Who insists on running up a slope, is confused and crazy.
Who is blind, dumb and deaf will live a peaceful life of a hundred years.
Who is defeated by words is not always convinced by the truth.
Who is late and not missed, mustn't call himself missing.
Who leaves the old way for the new, the trouble not looked for, will be found there.
Who likes you well will come to your house.
Who openly admires, will not buy.
Who pays in advance eats stinking fish.
Who poorly supports himself, soon falls.
Who pounds the water in the mortar, will get wet with the drops and will end up tired.
Who practices with the lame will be able to limp within a year.
Who preaches to the deaf, wastes the sermon.
Who resolves problems, doesn't die.
Who rids himself of his own freedom, always finds himself with worry and pain.
Who robs commits a sin, who is robbed commits a hundred.
Who runs more, lacks walking.
Patti, has beautiful fruits.
Peace won't settle where a woman rules.
Pears, fill the chest; prunes, eat one.
Pee on the ruins before they build a temple over them.
People with money and friends don't esteem justice.
Petrafendola from Modica, Bread from Ragusa, and olives from Chiaramonte.
Pigeon and chick, by your beak you attain beauty.
Pigs and children will turn out the way you teach them.
Pilate was neither saved nor damned.
Plain oil cures every pain.
Marriage must occur early or it will never happen.
Marriage would be beautiful if it weren't for cradle rocking.
Marriages and bishoprics are arranged in heaven.
Married people and mules, leave them alone.
Marry your children with their peers so you won't regret it someday.
May waters drench peasants and lords or gentlemen, as many of them as it encounters.
Meager possessions are highly valued.
Meat makes meat, bread makes a paunch, and wine makes you dance.
Men are not weighed by hundredweight, but by the ounce, like gold.
Men in glass houses should not throw stones.
Who doesn't want a fire, should remove the wood.
Who doesn't want to stay with friends, is either a cop, a cuckold, or a spy.
Who doesn't want to when he can, can't when he wants to.
Who dresses in the clothing of others, will soon undress.
Who drinks at night, buys himself death, who drinks in bed, buys himself a coffin.
Who drives donkeys and believes women, will never see the face of paradise.
Who eats without drinking, will never feel full.
Who fails to listen to his elders, will hang his knapsack in the wrong place.
Who fails to show restraint in their youth, will be miserable in their old age.
Who gets angry without reason, makes peace without satisfaction.
Put a heavy load on an old donkey.
Put up with your present condition to avoid a bad future.
Putting hope in a monk, is like trying to catch the wind in a net.
Quickly, quickly because the wax is melting.
Rain and the hoe make onions.
Raising children engenders love.
Reins and a whip make a good horse.
Religion will perish because of excessive comforts.
Remain continuously in the vegetable and flower garden.
Remain honorable and don't worry if you're poor.
The thief who can't steal anymore has become a Christian.
The time for pressing is while the iron is hot.
The tongue is the mirror of the stomach.
The tree in the middle of the road is shaken by everyone.
The tree that's cut down is half taken.
The turtle is not afraid of hail stones.
The unmarried don't know about labor pains.
The unscrupulous steal everything.
The vine always says to his uncle Frank: Make me poor and I'll make you rich.
The vineyard along the coast costs dearly.
Inexperienced young men are better off not marrying: Stay away from women! you'll be better off.
Involuntary love is worthless.
It is written in sacred scripture: where grass is growing you don't need fertilizer.
It takes bales of hundredweight because a fire of straw lasts little.
It takes both luck and good fortune just to fry eggs.
It won't work to tell your feet: come.
It's a bad sign when the sick person tosses and turns in bed.
It's a good marriage when he's twenty eight and she's eighteen.
It's a great advantage to love someone in your neighborhood: you see each other often and you don't have to travel.
It's a long way from the said to the done.
September brings acorn and olives.
Serve the Lord and you'll see what pain is.
Set the sails according to the wind.
She has a great marriage without a mother-in-law or a sister-in-law.
Sickness is a visit by God.
Sickness is awful, but a relapse is worse.
Sickness, if it doesn't kill, it purifies.
Silence is the soul of negotiation.
Sister Nicola said: Don't put the pasta basket in the water until it's boiling.
Sit, sit, daughter, sit, because good fortune is coming.
Who stays vigilant, will win.
Who suffers because of love, feels no pain.
Who takes cover under the branch, collects what rains and collects what falls.
Who teaches another, acquires more knowledge.
Who ventures forth, succeeds.
Who waits hoping in plans and dreams, loses time, and collects flies and troubles.
Who walks gains, who sits withers.
Who wants to chase two rabbits, will get neither one nor the other.
Who wants to eat snails, will have to get his feet wet.
Who wants to judge needs to listen to the parties.
The pigeon brings the makings and the chick makes the nest.
The poor and wretched man has long days.
The poor are the needy.
The poor didn't have but gave to charity.
The poor is not believed.
The poverty of the gentleman is better than the money of the poor man.
The priest covers the chalice and we must cover each other.
The prior said to the abbess: without money no Mass will be sung.
The promises of love and the smoke of a chimney, washed by water and blown away by the wind.
The pursued runs on four feet, the pursuer on two.
The female of the species is more deadly than the male.
The first seeding on the feast of All Saints and the last on the feast of Saint Andrew.
The fish was so fresh that it was being cooked while its tail was still in the sea.
The fourth fever kills the old and cures the young.
The fresh air from the square is better than a draft from a crack.
The gallows is not made for the rich, but for the head of the peasant.
The gluttony of the monk and the appetite of the priest.
The good sailor is proven in a storm.
The good that follows evil is more appreciated.
The good that you fail to do is gone forever.
When there's little meat, take the bone.
When there's love, mountains seem like plains.
When they give you a piglet, run there quickly with a little cord.
When things are being thrown away, buy them.
When you can't do what you want, do what you can.
When you fall behind, you eat dust.
When you go to steal a sheep and you're succeeding, take a big one because the small one will grow.
When you have brains to go along with your wealth you can call yourself happy and content.
When you have money you live happily, when you don't you lose your friends
When you have, you are.
When the fields are flooded you'll have hunger, when they're snow covered there'll be plenty to eat.
When the hunt is not successful, go find snails.
When the hunting dog barks it's a signal that the prey is near.
When the husband is a hen and the wife is a cock, the house is in a jumble.
When the moon is pale, it will rain; when it's red, it will be windy and when it's clear, it will be serene.
When the old man falls, don't laugh, the young have also fallen.
When the olive tree blooms during April, olives are harvested with barrels, when it blossoms in June, they are harvested in handfuls.
When the ox is at the slaughterhouse everyone comes running with their knives.
When the partridge sings in the stone quarry bring the wood into the haystack.
When the pear is ripe it falls by itself.
When loves knocks, be sure to answer.
When sweethearts want each other, the parents must inevitably accede.
When the cat hops around, bad weather is on the way.
When the cat washes its face, you know it's going to rain.
When the cat's away the mice will play.
When the cost is high think about it, when it's low, buy a lot.
When the crane passes, urge the oxen on.
When the dripping continues it succeeds in piercing the hardest stone.
When the ear of corn hangs to the side the farmer watches it with comfort.
When the fever is gone, the thirst ends.
Water, advice, and salt unasked for should not be given.
We go forward in order to go backwards.
We have but one soul to lose.
We keep an eye on the scorpion and the serpent, but we do not watch out for the millipede.
We learn by standing on the shoulders of the wise.
We're many rivers from the same water.
Wealth and holiness, believe only half, if you believe less, you'll do better.
Weapons are of no use to the fearful.
What good is faith if you don't live by it.
What has the rooster of Sciacca been reduced to, to be pecked by the hen.
Whoever rides into the flood, either does not own the animal or doesn't value it.
Whoever seeds fava beans without using fertilizer, shouldn't count on having much to eat.
Whoever sows alongside the road, tires the oxen and wastes seed.
Whoever sows on hard ground, needs good wishes and luck.
Whoever sows within the vineyard, neither reaps a crop nor harvests grapes.
Whoever waits for time to pass loses time.
Whoever wants a good must should hoe the vineyard in August.
Wine in moderation is a stomach tonic.
Wine is as sweet as honey but it can be abused.
Wine should not be watered.
Throw January cabbages in the garbage.
Ticks and money are difficult to pluck out.
Tie the burden securely and go off singing.
Tie the donkey where the owner wants, and let the wolf come to devour him.
Time marches on.
Timely rain cheers my soul; water and sun during seeding, inspires hope; the rains of April and May are late at night; then the good mornings, will be the wealth of the houses.
To appear and not to be is like weaving and not making cloth.
To be rich with bees and mares, is to be rich and have nothing.
To be worth as much as the H in the ABCs.
To cure a cold you need the warmth of a pigeon's nest.
Oh, oh, oh! three times I say it, who falls into poverty loses his friends.
Old age is desired, but when it comes, it's detested.
Old wood lights better but burns out quicker.
Olives harvested with a heavy staff will produce poor tasting oil.
On Saint Candelora day, if it's snowing or raining, there'll be another forty days of winter.
On the new year daylight increases as much as a man's stride.
Once broken, the pack-saddle will follow.
Once you've used enough seasoning; using more will spoil the dish.
One beautiful day doesn't make a summer.
One hair from the head of a woman pulls more than a ship's hauser.
The war is lost for too much advice.
The weak who opposes the strong, is like the jug that collides with the wall.
The weaker the patient is, the sooner the sickness will end.
The weight of years is the heaviest load.
The white head often lacks good sense.
The wild pear has blossomed: the kid goat no longer suffers.
The winner is looked upon as the stronger.
The woman like the hen, gets lost if she walks too far.
The woman without a husband doesn't have a friend.
The worker expects to be paid.
When death is near, neither doctors nor medicine help.
When everything is going smoothly, a man tends to get cocky.
When fava beans are flowering, apply water in torrents.
When February is rainy, it's very profitable.
When God wants to help you, he comes all the way to your house.
When in March sun and water are taking turns with water and sun, the mules end up doing the carrying.
When in Rome, do as the Romans.
sicilian.description: Act the way that the people around you are acting. This phrase might come in handy when youre traveling abroad notice that people do things differently than youre used to.

sicilian.text: When it rains in the morning, take the plow and start sowing; when it rains between Vespers and nightfall, put on your boots.
When it's seen, there's no need for proof.
When loves is willing, it finds a way.
With a clear Sirocco and a dark North Wind, go to sea without concern.
With a good farm, garden and vineyard, all your problems will be cured.
With death you don't lose hope: damnation is called separation.
With everything Messina has the port, but for beautiful Palermo it is always just an orchard.
With friends make agreements, with relatives make contracts.
With selling and buying there are neither friends nor cronies.
With the hammer's blows the defects become known.
With two bits worth of a donkey you can earn more than with a mule.
Without jealousy, love would wither.
Wives from the mountains and husbands from the cities.
The scales tip where the weight is.
The September moon governs seven moons.
The service is rendered, the goods awaited.
The short donkey doesn't carry on his back.
The Sicilian horse: short and dwarf.
The sick bed makes the doctor.
The soul goes to God, the body to the earth, and belongings to those to whom they should go.
The suffering patient knows more than the expert doctor.
The summer that yields lots of pumpkins and horse radish doesn't fill the larder.
The testimony of one eyewitness is worth more than the hearsay of a hundred.
Woe unto the patient whose doctors argue.
Women always tend to the bad.
Women and cloth should not be bought in the evening.
Women can't keep secrets.
Women, fire, and the sea are perilous for man.
Wooden casks make good wine.
Words are for reasoning.
Wrongful acquisitions don't last long.
Wrongful gains are quickly consumed.
You can correct a mistake.
Where there is no love there is no charity.
Where there's a senior the minor yields, said the chick in the cage.
Where there's smoke, there's fire.
Where you're not known, you're judged by your appearance.
While there's nothing to do in April, let out the herd to pasture with all the sheep.
While we are the Pope we'll pontificate; who knows if we'll be Pope another time.
While you still have bread, troubles are not troubles, true troubles are without bread.
White wine strengthens the hip.
Who approaches women penniless will be told: get lost.
Who arrives at the mill first, grinds.
There are two powers to contend with, those with a lot and those with nothing.
There is always the calm sea before the storm.
There is nary a feast or a party without a monk or a priest.
There is no knowledge without experience.
There is no master who can fix the ravages of old age.
There is no table without wine nor sermon without Augustine.
There is no victory without sacrifice.
There is rarely gain without deception.
There isn't a Holy Week without the fifty days, nor the fifty days without the Sirocco.
There isn't a Pentecost without a Sirocco nor a woman without a bow.
You'll realize he was a friend when you lose him and see him no more.
You'll regret in vain when you scorn good advice.
You're blessed if you're here on Leap year.
You're bound to leave some grain when you harvest.
You're never too old to learn.
You're not poor if you have as much as you need.
You're wasting your time trying to interest the old in new endeavors.
You're young if you're healthy, and rich if you have no debts.
Your canine teeth can take you to the grave.
Your looks betray your thoughts.
Who seeks that which he must not, finds that which he wants not.
Who seeks, finds; who perseveres, wins.
Who seizes too much with his own hand, will have everything slip away and will hold nothing.
Who sells, goes down; who buys, goes up.
Who serves God, fears nothing.
Who serves well and quietly, expects a lot.
Who sins and then makes amends, trusts in God.
Who spares himself while young, will work until he's old.
Who starts many things, finishes nothing.
Who stays at the master and doesn't learn, is either a jackass or pretends to be one.
You get work from the young and advice from the old.
You learn by teaching.
You may crush, bleed, stamp on and scratch me, but I won't play with fire.
You need firm care to cure deep melancholy.
You need four men to make a good salad: a crazy man to mix it, a scholar for the salt, a miser for a touch of vinegar, and a squanderer for the oil.
You need land to seed, to live in luxury.
You need plant only one cherry and one plum tree.
You need to first experience adversity, before you can handle high praise.
You need to have patience in storms: you don't eat honey without flies.
You never get enough of kissing a sweetheart or eating snails.
Use your time as best you can, keeping the hoe and oxen ready.
Use your time in May to stock up for winter.
Vegetable garden and mill, don't tell your neighbor how much they yield.
Wait for time and lose time.
Walk with your slippers until you can find your shoes.
Walls don't have ears but they hear, they don't have mouths but they speak.
Watch out for the unexpected mushroom.
Water and sun make work, water and wind make grain.
Water does harm but wine comforts.
Water does harm but wine makes you sing.
When the poor man patches himself up, he seems newly dressed.
When the ripened ears are full and fall over, as if in sleep, the farmer awakens, that is to say, he begins the harvest.
When the rooster crows off the hour, don't hesitate to adjust the time.
When the screech-owl sings, you can try to go to work for someone else if you're working for a bad owner.
When the sickness is old not even Hippocrates can help.
When the Sirocco blows in the winter, you can expect rain at any moment.
When the weather changes, the beast sneezes.
When there are lots of insects, look for a good grain year.
When there is poverty, loyalty is suspect.
When there's a clear horizon in winter, there'll be the devil to pay.
Who lives foolishly as a youth, wails in old age.
Who looks for a quarrel, finds a quarrel.
Who loses his honor loses a lot, who loses his faith, loses everything.
Who loses honor won't ever find it.
Who loves God with all his heart, lives happy and dies happy.
Who loves with his heart sees from a distance.
Who makes baskets, makes some ugly and some beautiful.
Who makes excuses without being accused, shows his guilt.
Who makes himself a sheep, will be eaten by the wolf.
Who makes the hundred and not the one, loses the hundred because of that one.
Whoever brings his wife to every feast will not be lacking for headaches.
Whoever buys useless things will soon be selling his necessities.
Whoever cultivates clay, harvests silk.
Whoever exchanges gets rid of the coarse and the bad.
Whoever exchanges some lard for some other lard, one or the other must be rancid.
Whoever falls in love with an old person laments their fortune.
Whoever goes on foot during April and May, goes on horseback the rest of the year.
Whoever goes to Palermo and doesn't see Monreale, goes there a jackass and returns a fool.
Whoever interferes between husband and wife is a big jackass.
Whoever marries for love will always live in pain.
You never value something as much as when it's gone.
You only fool yourself when you seed badly.
You shout in vain when you're calling the deaf.
You want a grumpy dog and a lively horse.
You will not be loved if you only think of yourself.
You won't know who your friends are until you need them.
You'll become a lot better if you think about your death.
You'll begin to be rich when you learn to scorn riches.
You'll know the good soldier in battle.
You'll never be sated with bread and olives.
Your most faithful friends are your own hands.
Your value is set by your worth.
Your word is your bond.
Youth spent freely, old age spent in poverty.
Who gets married to a thin woman will know bitterness and strife, who marries a plump woman will be contented at the table and sleeping chamber.
Who gets married will be happy for a day, who butchers a pig will be happy for a year.
Who goes hunting without dogs, comes home without rabbits.
Who goes out in the morning finds a carlin.
Who goes to the fair without money, goes with one problem and returns with three.
Who got up, lost his place, who sat down, found it.
Who has a priest at home, has plenty of food.
Who has cold hands is in love, who has warm hands is loved.
Who has convenience and doesn't seize it, tie him to a stall and give him straw.
Who has lived a good life has a good death.
You can tell an educated person by their talk and bells by their ringing.
You can't drive donkeys without a stick, nor horses without spurs.
You can't fight City Hall.
You can't have meat without the bone.
You can't kill your way into heaven.
You can't live a long life and remain upright.
You can't make a rattle with a single walnut in a sack.
You can't punch your way into heaven.
You can't shame the wicked.
You can't sleep and be on guard.
Ammuccia lu latinu 'gnuranza di parrinu.
sicilian.description: Latin hides the stupidity of the priest.

sicilian.text: Fidi sarva, no lignu di varca.
sicilian.description: Faith is salvation, not the wood of a ship.

sicilian.text: Jiri 'n celu ognunu v; l'armu cc', li forzi no.
sicilian.description: Everyone wants to go to heaven; the desire is there but the fortitude is not.

sicilian.text: Lu pintimentu lava lu piccatu.
sicilian.description: Repentance washes away sin.

sicilian.text: Lu Signiuruzzu li cosi, li fici dritti, vinni lu diavulu e li sturcu.
sicilian.description: God made things straight, the devil came and twisted them.

sicilian.text: Zoccu  datu da Diu, nun p mancari.
sicilian.description: What is given by God, can't be lacking.

sicilian.text: Accatta caru e vinni mircatu.
sicilian.description: Buy good quality and sell at the market price.

sicilian.text: Accatta di quattru e vinni d'ottu.
sicilian.description: Buy at the cost of four and sell at the cost of eight.

sicilian.text: Cu' accatta abbisogna di cent'occhi; cu' vinni d'un sulu.
sicilian.description: Buyer beware.

sicilian.text: Cui nun voli pagari, s'assuggetta ad ogni pattu.
sicilian.description: Who doesn't intend to pay, signs any contract.

sicilian.text: La scarsizza fa lu prezzu.
sicilian.description: Scarcity sets the price.

sicilian.text: Omu dinarusu, omu pinsirusu.
sicilian.description: A wealthy man is a pensive man.

sicilian.text: Riccu si p diri cui campa cu lu so' aviri.
sicilian.description: One who lives within his means can be said to be rich.

sicilian.text: Sggiri prestamenti, pagari tardamenti; cu' sa qualchi accidenti, non si ni paga nenti.
sicilian.description: Collect promptly, pay slowly; who knows, in case of an accident, you'll pay nothing.

sicilian.text: Unni cc' oru, cc' stolu.
sicilian.description: Gold attracts a crowd.

sicilian.text: Zicchi e dinari su' forti a scippari.
sicilian.description: Ticks and money are difficult to pluck out.

sicilian.text: Mancia cudu e vivi friddu.
sicilian.description: Eat warm and drink cold.

sicilian.text: Mancia di sanu e vivi di malatu.
sicilian.description: Eat with gusto but drink in moderation.

sicilian.text: Non c' megghiu sarsa di la fami.
sicilian.description: Hunger is the best sauce.

sicilian.text: Aprili fa li ciuri e le biddizzi, l'onuri l'havi lu misi di maju.
sicilian.description: April makes the flowers and the beauty, but May gets all the credit.

sicilian.text: Burrasca furiusa prestu passa.
sicilian.description: A furious storm passes quickly.

sicilian.text: Frivareddu  curtuliddu, ma nun c' cchi tintu d'iddu.
sicilian.description: February may be short but it's the worst month.

sicilian.text: Giugnettu, lu frummentu sutta lu lettu.
sicilian.description: In July, store the grain under the bed.

sicilian.text: Misi di maju, mttiti 'n casa ligna e furmaggiu.
sicilian.description: Use your time in May to stock up for winter.

sicilian.text: Pruvulazzu di jinnaru crrica lu sularu.
sicilian.description: A dry January means a filled hayloft.

sicilian.text: Si jinnaru 'un jinnara, frivaru malu pensa.
sicilian.description: If it isn't wintry in January then expect the worst in February.

sicilian.text: Una bedda jurnata nun fa stati.
sicilian.description: One beautiful day doesn't make a summer.

sicilian.text: batti lu ferru mentri  cudu
sicilian.description: common in English, too, such as batti lu ferru mentri  cudu ("strike while the iron is hot"). The sayings below can be used in a variety of situations.

sicilian.text: A paisi unni chi vai, comu vidi fari fai.
sicilian.description: When in Rome, do as the Romans do.

sicilian.text: Batti lu ferru mentri  cudu.
sicilian.description: Strike while the iron is hot.

sicilian.text: Cani abbaia e voi pasci.
sicilian.description: Dogs bark and oxen graze.

sicilian.text: Cu' vigghia, la pigghia.
sicilian.description: The early bird catches the worm.

sicilian.text: Cui cerca, trova; cui scuta, vinci.
sicilian.description: Who seeks, finds; who perseveres, wins.

sicilian.text: Cui multi cosi accumenza, nudda nni finisci.
sicilian.description: Who starts many things, finishes nothing.

sicilian.text: Cui scerri cerca, scerri trova.
sicilian.description: Who looks for a quarrel, finds a quarrel.

sicilian.text: Di guerra, caccia e amuri, pri un gustu milli duluri.
sicilian.description: In war, hunting, and love you suffer a thousand pains for one pleasure.

sicilian.text: gran pazzia lu cuntrastari cu du' nun p vinciri n appattari.
sicilian.description: It's insane to oppose when you can neither win nor compromise.

sicilian.text: Li ricchi cchi chi nn'hannu, cchi nni vonnu.
sicilian.description: The more you have, the more you want.

sicilian.text: 'Ntra greci e greci nun si vinni abbraciu.
sicilian.description: There's honor among thieves.

sicilian.text: Nun mttiri lu carru davanti li voi.
sicilian.description: Don't put the cart before the horse.

sicilian.text: Ogni mali nun veni pri nciri.
sicilian.description: Not every pain comes to harm you.

sicilian.text: Quannu amuri tuppula, 'un lu lassari 'nmenzu la via.
sicilian.description: When love knocks, be sure to answer.

sicilian.text: Supra lu majuri si 'nsigna lu minuri.
sicilian.description: We learn by standing on the shoulders of the wise.

sicilian.text: Unni cc' focu, pri lu fumu pari.
sicilian.description: Where there's smoke, there's fire.

sicilian.text: Vali cchi un tistimonu di visu, chi centu d'oricchia.
sicilian.description: The testimony of one eyewitness is worth more than the hearsay of a hundred.

sicilian.text: Dont compromise your beliefs for money.
You may garnish it with as much salt and pepper as you want, but pumpkin still has little flavor.
Respect is measured: whoever pays it to others, will be respected.
You cant have meat without the bone.
After August, winter starts.
He who preservers shall win.
Sing to the mother-in-law, listen to the sister-in-law.
A pious doctor makes putrid wounds.
Theres two types of powerful, those who own too much and those who dont own a thing.
An unfulfilled vow is as if it had not been made.
February may be short but its the worst month.
Home for as long as you need to be, and land as far as the eye can see.
Who doesnt intend to pay, signs any contract.
Those who cause harm first, can expect greater harm in return.
Love is like a cough impossible to hide.
Wherever the donkey falls, he stands up.
Whoever decides to change is aware of not knowing what the change may bring.
Theres honor among thieves.
If you invest a lot but dont maintain it, you wont even harvest enough to re-seed.
It is better to be alone than to be in bad company.
When the cats away the mice will play.
Noon is attracted to who they do not resemble .
Time is precious.
Those who still have a young daughter..cannot speak badly about other women!
Where theres smoke, theres fire.
Who walks with the cripple, sooner or later will start limping.
The mouse said to the nut: give me time and I shall reach you.
A cuckold in his own town is better than an idiot anywhere else.
Who leaves  their own comfort zone  succeeds!
The vase filled with water, sooner or later will break or crash.
Dont put the cart before the horse.
Its insane to oppose when you can neither win nor compromise.
With old men and flowering cabbagesthere is nothing left to do.
Collect promptly, pay slowly; who knows, in case of an accident, youll pay nothing.
It cant get any darker than midnight.
When love knocks, be sure to answer.
If it isnt wintry in January then expect the worst in February.
If the devil pays you compliments, he wants your soul.
What is given by God, cant be lacking.
Theres no grain to collect, nor women to marry.
One beautiful day doesnt make a summer.
Whoever goes to Palermo and doesnt see Monreale, goes there a jackass and returns a fool.
